docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, Heather Jones got an unusual letter in the mail from the nurse at her son's school in Pennsylvania. The letter said her 9-year-old son was too fat. Mrs. Jones was one of about 400 parents in the school district of 6,700 students to receive the same news. Mrs. Jones, who, after all, sees her son every day and knows what he looks like, was not happy about it.

headline.main: Letters on Students' Weight Ruffle Parents

docs.abstract: Article on resistance and resentment by some parents in handful of school districts in Pennyslvania and Florida that are notifying them by letter that their children are overweight and at risk for future health problems; parents of severely underweight children were also notified, but none of them complained; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Last month, Heather Jones got an unusual letter in the mail from the nurse at her son's school in Pennsylvania. The letter said her 9-year-old son was too fat. Mrs. Jones was one of about 400 parents in the school district of 6,700 students to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Let me start with some good news for the many millions of people who have been told that they have diverticulosis and should avoid eating foods containing small seeds and that they should never eat nuts. It turns out that this longstanding bit of medical wisdom was based on virtually no scientific evidence, just guesswork, and unless you have already developed inflamed or infected diverticula, your diet need not be so restricted, most experts say.

headline.main: Diverticulosis, an Ill of the Affluent Life

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on diverticulosis, its symptoms, prevention and treatment; notes disease has become common in America and other well-developed countries, where diet is replete with processed foods and lacks fruits, vegetables and whole grains; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Let me start with some good news for the many millions of people who have been told that they have diverticulosis and should avoid eating foods containing small seeds and that they should never eat nuts.    It turns out that this longstanding bit of...

docs.lead_paragraph: If predictions of global warming prove true, allergy sufferers may have it especially bad. Researchers at Harvard have found that a higher level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which contributes to global warming, acts like a supercharger for ragweed, the bane of many people with allergies.

headline.main: Climate Change: Something to Sneeze At

docs.abstract: Researchers at Harvard University find that higher level of carbon dioxide in atmosphere, which contributes to global warming, is helping ragweed to thrive and triggering allergy attacks; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: If predictions of global warming prove true, allergy sufferers may have it especially bad.    Researchers at Harvard have found that a higher level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which contributes to global warming, acts like a supercharger for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jeffrey P. Koplan, the departing director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, defended again yesterday his agency's handling of the anthrax attack and the way the investigation was communicated to the public. Dr. Koplan spoke in an interview as he announced that he would become vice president for academic health affairs at Emory University, which like the disease control agency is in Atlanta.

headline.main: Director Defends C.D.C.'s Handling of Anthrax Attacks

docs.abstract: Departing Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director Jeffrey Koplan, in interview, again defends agency's handling of anthrax attack and way it was communicated to health professionals and public; denies he threatened to resign in first days of attack unless CDC was allowed to address public; comments on politics involved in public health issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fewer than half the estimated 28 million migraine sufferers in the United States seek medical attention for the ailment, a new study has found. The study, in the current issue of Neurology, is based on 4,376 people who reported having migraines and concludes that the overall incidence of the condition remains basically unchanged over the past 10 years.
docs.abstract: Albert Einstein College of Medicine study finds that fewer than half estimated 28 million migraine sufferers in US seek medical attention for ailment; also finds that 49 percent of those surveyed treat themselves only with over-the-counter drugs (S)
docs.snippet: Fewer than half the estimated 28 million migraine sufferers in the United States seek medical attention for the ailment, a new study has found.    The study, in the current issue of Neurology, is based on 4,376 people who reported having migraines...

docs.lead_paragraph: As a rule, doctors give stress tests only to patients who have symptoms of heart disease like chest pain. But two new studies suggest that use of the tests, in which heart function is measured as a patient uses a treadmill, should be expanded. Researchers from Johns Hopkins say that even in men and women without symptoms, the tests can offer a clear signal of heart problems ahead.

headline.main: An Upgraded Role for Stress Tests

docs.abstract: Two studies presented at American College of Cardiology conference in Atlanta suggest that stress tests should be given to men and women with high cholesterol or heart problems in their families, not just patients with symptoms of heart disease; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: As a rule, doctors give stress tests only to patients who have symptoms of heart disease like chest pain. But two new studies suggest that use of the tests, in which heart function is measured as a patient uses a treadmill, should be expanded.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Do you have flushing?'' the gastroenterologist repeatedly asked my wife early last year. Days before, she had had a routine colonoscopy, and now the doctor was asking her if her face was turning bright red, and if she was sweating uncontrollably. Except for a few gastrointestinal problems over the years, Carol felt fine. But she wasn't. She had cancer. Thinking she had an irritable bowel, the doctor had directed the probe a few inches into her small intestine. A small, one centimeter nodule -- a polyp, he figured -- was found and biopsied. It was not a polyp, but a rare carcinoid tumor.

headline.main: Rare Tumor Is Deceptive And Deadly

docs.abstract: Eric Taub Cases column describes symptoms, diagnosis and treatment of rare carcinoid tumors which, if not caught early, can be deadly; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ''Do you have flushing?'' the gastroenterologist repeatedly asked my wife early last year. Days before, she had had a routine colonoscopy, and now the doctor was asking her if her face was turning bright red, and if she was sweating uncontrollably....

docs.lead_paragraph: Divorce often hurts children, everyone agrees. It can cause great pain, anger, anxiety, confusion and behavior problems in the first couple of years of the breakup. And for some it leads to lasting anxiety, insecurity and fear of having close relationships with other people. Most children recover, though it may take years, and go on to find happiness and success in marriage, work and life. Experts agree about that, too. But from this general accord arises a heated dispute between those who emphasize the pain and those who think more attention should be paid to the children's recovery.

headline.main: 2 Portraits of Children of Divorce: Rosy and Dark

docs.abstract: Article on opposing books about effect of divorce on children; discusses findings of University of Virginia emeritus Prof E Mavis Hetherington, co-author, with John Kelly, of For Better or For Worse: Divorce Reconsidered, and Dr Judith S Wallerstein, co-author, with Dr Julia M Lewis and Sandra Blakeslee, of The Unexpected Legacy of Divorce: A 25-Year Landmark Study; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Diet may affect the amount of pain that patients with long-term illnesses suffer, say researchers who have been exploring the role of soy in pain management. So far, the researchers say, their work has been limited to laboratory animals. But the results have been promising enough that they hope to expand it to people.

headline.main: Soy May Play Role in Pain Management

docs.abstract: Study by Johns Hopkins researchers Srinivasa Raja and Jill Tall, presented at American Pain Society conference in Baltimore, finds that rats given diet high in defatted soy flour have less swelling when injured and show less response to pain than rats on different diets (S)
docs.snippet: Diet may affect the amount of pain that patients with long-term illnesses suffer, say researchers who have been exploring the role of soy in pain management.    So far, the researchers say, their work has been limited to laboratory animals. But the...

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent look at the cases of more than 5,000 hospital patients found that about one-fourth were treated by medical specialists working out of their area of expertise, and the patients may have paid a price for it. The study, in a recent issue of The Archives of Internal Medicine, found that patients who were treated by these doctors tended to have longer hospital stays and slightly higher mortality rates.

headline.main: Doctor's Specialty Is Special to Patients

docs.abstract: Study published in Archives of Internal Medicine finds that of 5,000 hospital cases reviewed, about 25 percent of patients were treated by medical specialists working outside their area of expertise; finds those patients tended to have longer hospital stays and slightly higher mortality rates than those treated by primary care doctors; drawing (M)
